A family (x_i)_{i in I} of elements of an A-module M is called free or linearly independent if from an equation sum_{i in I} a_i x_i = 0 with coefficients a_i in A we can conclude that a_i = 0 for all i in I. A free system of generators will also be referred to as a basis.

An A-module M is called a free A-module if it has a basis, i.e., a free system of generators. In this case, every element x in M admits a representation x = sum_{i in I} a_i x_i with coefficients a_i in A that are unique.
Does the concept of a/an Free system of generators (basis) need to be defined for a definition of a/an Free A-module to make sense? (True if the first concept is needed and False if is not.)

Explanation: The definition of a Free A-module explicitly states that it is an A-module that has a basis, which is defined as a free system of generators. Therefore, the concept of a free system of generators (basis) is integral to understanding what constitutes a free A-module. Without the concept of a free system of generators, we would not be able to define what it means for an A-module to be free, as the definition relies on the existence of a basis to provide a unique representation for every element in the module. Thus, the concept of a free system of generators is necessary for the definition of a free A-module to make sense.
